results.title: Early trick films [1898-1912]
results.brief_description: Compilation including “The House that Jack built” (dir. G.A. Smith); “Upside down or the human flies” (dir. R.W. Paul); “The Brahmin and the butterfly” (dir. Georges Melies); “The Motorist” (dir. R.W. Paul); “The Magic screen”; “Dante’s inferno”; and in its entirety, “The Invisible thief”.

results.title: Early stone tools
results.creator_credit: Extension Media Center, University of California and Clyde B Smith
results.brief_description: Traces the development of stone tools and parallels their development with the evolution of man from austropithecus to homo sapiens. Demonstrates percussion flaking techniques to produce a variety of tools. Shows actual prehistoric tools.

results.title: Early starters
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Six of the best”.
Raises several definitions of work by looking at the various forms of employment and unemployment situations in which the six school leavers find themselves.

results.title: Early sound recording equipment
results.brief_description: In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.

constellations_primary.name: Amateur hour
constellations_primary.description: Early sound equipment allowed filmmakers and amateurs alike the ability to experiment often with affordable 16mm film.

results.description:
Filmmakers had been trying to record sound on film since motion pictures were invented in the late 1800s but commercial systems for recording sound directly onto film took years of experimenting and innovating.

By 1929, synchronised sound, including Warner Brothers’ sound-on-disc Vitaphone system and RCA Photophone’s electrical sound-on-film system, were debuted. Once the technology was discovered, it only took five years for it to be available to amateur filmmakers.

In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.
description_for_label:
Filmmakers had been trying to record sound on film since motion pictures were invented in the late 1800s but commercial systems for recording sound directly onto film took years of experimenting and innovating.

By 1929, synchronised sound, including Warner Brothers’ sound-on-disc Vitaphone system and RCA Photophone’s electrical sound-on-film system, were debuted. Once the technology was discovered, it only took five years for it to be available to amateur filmmakers.

In 1935, the world’s first sound-on-film camera was released for the amateur market, the RCA Victor Sound 16mm camera. Like RCA’s Photophone system, it recorded sound directly onto the film’s edge via light reflected off a mirror, which was attached to a diaphragm that vibrated when the operator spoke.

results.title: Early sound films
results.brief_description: Short extracts from the following early sound films which were milestones in the history of Cinema: ‘The Jazz Singer’, ‘The Lights of New York’, ‘On With The Show’, ‘Show of Shows’, ‘In Old Arizona’, ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’.

results.title: Early social behaviour
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Yale Clinic of Child Development and Arnold Gesell
results.brief_description: Shows the manifestation of the infant personality in a variety of social settings. Ten different children from 8 weeks to 7 years of age are studied and individual differences are emphasised. Also the social significance of the household is conveyed by scenes that reflect parent-child relationships.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Yale Clinic of Child Development and Arnold Gesell
